description: From Middle English passioun, passion, from Old French passion (and in part from Old English passion), from Latin passio (‚Äúsuffering‚Äù), noun of action from perfect passive participle passus (‚Äúsuffered‚Äù), from deponent verb patior (‚ÄúI suffer‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *peh‚ÇÅ- (‚Äúto hurt‚Äù), see also Old English fƒìond (‚Äúdevil, enemy‚Äù), Gothic êçÜêå∞êåπêå∞êåΩ (faian, ‚Äúto blame‚Äù).

entries.meaning: A true desire sustained or prolonged.
Any great, strong, powerful emotion, especially romantic love or extreme hate.
examples: We share a passion for books.

entries.meaning: An object of passionate or romantic love or strong romantic interest.
examples: It started as a hobby, but now my motorbike collection has become my passion.

entries.meaning: Sexual intercourse, especially when very emotional.
examples: We shared a night of passion.

entries.meaning: (Christianity, usually capitalized) The suffering of Jesus leading up to and during his crucifixion.
A display, musical composition, or play meant to commemorate the suffering of Jesus.
(obsolete) Suffering or enduring of imposed or inflicted pain; any suffering or distress.
(obsolete) The state of being acted upon; subjection to an external agent or influence; a passive condition
(obsolete) The capacity of being affected by external agents; susceptibility of impressions from external agents.
(obsolete) An innate attribute, property, or quality of a thing.
examples: [...] to obtain the knowledge of some passion of the circle.

verbs.description: passion (third-person singular simple present passions, present participle passioning, simple past and past participle passioned)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To suffer pain or sorrow; to experience a passion; to be extremely agitated.
examples: she passioned To see herself escap'd from so sore ills

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a passionate character to.
